page.title: 08QUARRYING; MENDIPS
page.content: The Mendip Hills are worth approximately Â£30,000,000,000 containing as they do, 40,000 million tons of limestone. The potential environmental damage is enormous. For many centuries stone has been quarried on the Mendips. When quarrying first started, the stone was only used locally for buildings and tracks. Most of the Mendips' natural crags and small cliffs are modified in a special way, especially in places where the stone was used for building. Later as transport improved, quarries grew in size and number to supply stone for roads, bridges and railways as well as buildings. The largest and best known quarries on Mendip are at Dulcote, Vobster, Gurney Slade, Water Lip, Emborough, Windsor Hill, Under Wood and Draycott.
